keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris was the site of a daylight robbery where thieves stole high-value jewellery estimated at €88 million.
The stolen items include a diamond and emerald necklace given by Napoleon I to his wife, a tiara worn by Empress Eugenie, and other pieces from Queen Marie-Amelie.
The thieves used power tools to break through a glass window in the Galerie d'Apollon, threatened guards, and escaped via scooters, leaving behind a damaged crown allegedly dropped during escape.
Security failures were identified, including lack of CCTV in one-third of rooms and failure of the broader alarm system to activate.
French President Emmanuel Macron described the heist as an attack on French heritage.
Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin blamed security protocol failures and criticized the public image of France's vulnerability.
Authorities believe the thieves were professionals, given the speed and coordination of the operation.
Experts warn that the stolen items are likely already broken down into precious metals and gems and smuggled abroad, reducing their value significantly.
The museum's curator, Laure Beccuau, emphasized that the true loss is not just financial but cultural and historical.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A daring daylight robbery at the Louvre Museum in Paris saw four masked thieves steal high-value jewellery, including a necklace from Napoleon I and a tiara from Empress Eugenie, estimated at €88 million. The thieves used a modified truck and power tools to gain entry, bypassing security systems, and escaped on scooters. Investigations reveal serious lapses in museum security, such as missing CCTV in one-third of rooms and a non-triggering alarm system. French officials, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, condemned the attack as a breach of national heritage. Experts believe the items have likely been melted down and smuggled abroad, with only days left to track them down before they are considered permanently lost.
title: Louvre heist: Stolen jewellery worth €88m, prosecutor says
